topic.title: Big File Splitting Test
topic.body:
I created a site to test my experimental script of downloading big files (currently 5MB). Can anyone have a look and test it out?
http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/

topic.title: ZeroNet big file support progress
topic.body:
Is any of these ZeroNet functionalities, ranking from easy to hard, planed for future development?
- UI for creating separate `content.json` files.
- Fetching a relatively big file from multiple peers simultaneously.
- "Super node" and packet routing (help two passive peers communicate).

topic.title: [zn-dev] Fuzz Testing ZeroNet
topic.body:
Let's go crazy. No fuzzing test case for ZeroNet has been deployed yet. Let's talk about how to crash ZeroNet via fuzzing!
- - -

## There are three major "public doorways" in ZeroNet:

- The FileServer, public to every peer in the network.
- The UiServer, on a gateway, public to every visitor.
- The ZeroFrame APIs, can be abused by JavaScript programs on a ZeroNet site.

I don't expect we can discover ZeroDay exploits by running casual fuzz testings. However, fuzz testing can help devs find unknown programming errors and improve program quality.
- - -

## How to fuzz ZeroNet?

For the FileServer, I can set up a socket and feed `os.urandom(4096)`. Here we are not only testing the robustness of `msgpack`. Therefore, to increase code coverage, we may have to use `msgpack` encoded messages.

How to tell if the result is unexpected?
- Error messages that say "exception" "OSError"  etc.
- Unexpected keys and values.
- Unexpected data types.
- Response can't be decoded by `msgpack`.
- No response after 5 seconds.
- The error reporting procedure in ZeroNet is not consistent (i.e. connection suddenly closed no matter what), which makes automatic testing hard. Add a `--test` arg and rewrite some server-side code?

For the UI server, I can use the `urllib` to get data put into the program, but I must have to find a way to prevent unwanted sites from being downloaded.

How to tell if the result is unexpected?
- Unexpected status code (i.e. 500 instead of 403. 200 instead of 404.)
- Invalid headers (i.e. `Access-Control-*` headers should not appear in HTML page responses)
- Wrapper nonces are not being invalidated (i.e. garbled wrapper_nonce or reused wrapper_nonce grants access to HTML content)
- HTTP response does not conform to RFC. (i.e. `\xd4\x9ax\x87\xac\xa5Srr\xbc\xd8.\xfd\xb8u` instead of `HTTP/1.1 200 OK`)
- No repsonse after 5 seconds

For the ZeroFrame APIs, I don't know how to fuzz it automatically. :(
- - -

## Help Needed
It's impossible for one to make all of these tests and keep the test cases updated. Collective ideas are needed to build better software. 

Do you have shiny ideas of generating garbled, malicious and well-crafted input specifically for ZeroNet? Write down your ideas.

Do you know how to fuzz WebSocket-based APIs? Tell us!

Do you have experience fuzz testing programs or crashing programs?   Please discuss it in the comments!

1_1LxkfGxtWhktAJ5WJ9ZnKxksTSH37qm8cC.body:
> [tkarita](#comment_119_1GervYZoP82e8X1Rgc4wyMkJY2zSsJuq8t): Nice.  In Firefox, the embedded player vanishes just after downloading, which makes the file difficult to play.  It seems to be reassembled successfully, though.

I added a link to download the file. Could you see it now?

> [tkarita](#comment_122_1GervYZoP82e8X1Rgc4wyMkJY2zSsJuq8t): Oops, I missed this.  The download link works well enough.  Is Firefox ignoring the usual methods for setting a default filename?

Yes. It is possibly a bug.

> [waterrabbit](#comment_7_1LxkfGxtWhktAJ5WJ9ZnKxksTSH37qm8cC): Yes. It is possibly a bug.

It is probably a bug of Firefox. The renaming works well in Chrome.

> [tkarita](#comment_123_1GervYZoP82e8X1Rgc4wyMkJY2zSsJuq8t): The video works better.  Strangely, Firefox's HTML5 player controls don't work, but "play" from the context menu does.  What are you using to chop up the files and hash the pieces?

Python.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/
Firefox users can now play the video when it is still being downloaded.
The player will show up when the first 1/5 of the progress bar has been filled.

Please click on the links labelled **Stream** if you would like to test this feature. I was not realized that the first two videos are not streaming friendly.

There is a Chrome bug that prevents the program from accessing Source Buffer in a sandboxed iframe. That bug has been found and reported several years ago, but not yet been fixed.
Thanks everyone who has been testing and seeding it. It is 50MB now, if you download **all** of the files.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V
Now the big file streaming script is checking the hash of the big, reassembled file in a Web Worker.

I tested it against a 200MB file. When the hash of the big file was being checked, the web page still responded to scrolling and video seeking.

Though it is not necessary to check the hash of the reassembled file, I worked out a way to use Web Workers in ZeroNet's `iframe` without running into any cross origin errors.

If a cross origin error causes `new Worker("async-hash.js");` and `importScripts('asmcrypto.js');` to fail, putting the content of the script into a `blob:` URL can bypass this error.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V
The MP4 multiplexer, written completely in JavaScript, is finally live on my website!
If you are using **Firefox**, you can **play any video** on that page as you are **buffering** it.

6_1KzaKud9cUZB7HcgHnhrZqyuq2NnTeW6PR.body:
> [jarmund](#comment_4_1CiHRyU3rHFGR1rEyTPDYH7xjN99iPZkBJ): Why? I'm not a Tor users but I don't know why is it a problem to have many Tor users on Zeronet?

ZeroNet's --proxy and --tor options do not work together, ~~so if you are using Tor, your will be connecting to Tor users only.~~

If more non-Tor users come, there can be more active seeders on the clear net.
If more Tor users come, there can be more active seeders on the Tor network.

5_1C6qdRAX8iYqSB7TfUxk91yW8Y2SBKNgfA.body:

Yeah, blame your browser... or simply, set your proxy to `0.0.0.0 : 6666`, no proxy for `127.0.0.1`

Have a look at Erkan's blog. http://127.0.0.1:43110/zeroblog.bit/?Post:60:protect+yourselves:+set+a+non-working+proxy

He wrote a blog for people who are highly paranoid, like me, but it's a pity that he is too busy in his real world life to continue writing now.
If you are really paranoid, being afraid of javascript exploits, you can also use a virtual machine.

1_1Nv4Sz7ExDb5tJBZt27RwWWkUvQ8JFosFM.body:
ZeroNet has an ["optional" file](https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/site_development/content_json/#optional) feature. An optional file is not downloaded and saved until a site visitor wants to see it.

ZeroNet also keeps track of site size and inform site visitors to increase the size limit.

2_1D9w8AJTfqmn26iT2kF81B8HxXFfycXuXM.body:
ZeroNet's developer is working on Big File Support, but the sole developer has other important things to do in his real life. If you are looking for a solution for transferring big files within ZeroNet for now, have a look at [ZeroMux](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/).

Generally, we want to keep sites as small as possible, because every visited site is saved in the `data/` folder, and if you move the files in it away, ZeroNet cannot find and seed them.

If there is really another ZeroNet network, people who can join the network can still access the data in that network, because the data are still public.

1_1KWfi9GbSvnLzLM3QbLSBhvRRiB2aq5rjH.body:
I think ZeroNet's optional file storage space can be made into two parts:
the "pinned" part and the "random" part.

In the "pinned" part, you save the files you like to read offline, and ZeroNet will NOT delete them automatically for you.

In the "random" part, you host random content you once downloaded but don't really care about, and ZeroNet will clean up the files in the "random" part periodically.

"Help distribute this user's all new files" -> `PinFiles( [file for file in optionalFiles if some_logic] )`
"Save this series of comics" -> "Download these files. Are you sure? (40MB)" -> `PinFiles( [file for file in optionalFiles if InUserDefinedGroup(file, "comic1")] )`

1_17iKAuuhDPPmh5cs8Ea465mTdnQiR8WaMK.body: Delete that site from your computer and try again.

4_137PNA5gLgCTLZTBtzUqCmMoZ752NQGQSJ.body: You are advised to keep your content.json as small as possible, since people visiting your site for the first time need to download the whole file.json before they can start downloading other site files.

https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/site_development/content_json/#includes
https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/site_development/content_json/#ignore

You can "include" your separate json files in your content.json
and make content.json "ignore" the files included in separate json files.

> [arsenelupin](#comment_6_137PNA5gLgCTLZTBtzUqCmMoZ752NQGQSJ):  overhead of having one content.json per book.json

You can have one separate book.json for every series of books. For example, all books published in 2015 can share one book.json. On the other hand, you may have to write a script to organize books and sign files.

You may need this command: `zeronet.py siteSign yoursite --inner_path books/2014/content.json`
Btw, can the GUI generate a separate content.json for me?

1_13GU1tjE8NpZocm8bZdSE83BmrbLfydR9V.body:
Create a site address using vanitygen. Make a folder using that public key in the `data` folder.
Put files into it. Then use ZeroNet to access that URL.
On the right sidebar, select "This is my site" and sign using your private key you just generated.

> [itsatest](#comment_3_13GU1tjE8NpZocm8bZdSE83BmrbLfydR9V): Do I need to put a specific content.json? Or will it be created automagically on first sign?

No need to put content.json

Here is another possible way (I didn't try it):
Clone ZeroBlog.
Go to the folder of your new public key.
Delete all contents; then put your own content there.
Sign.

2_1KWfi9GbSvnLzLM3QbLSBhvRRiB2aq5rjH.body: Do you mean attacking ZeroNet by deploying a lot of "dead" nodes? I came up with a ["weighted peer count"](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/1RedkCkVaXuVXrqCMpoXQS29bwaqsuFdL/1LxkfGxtWhktAJ5WJ9ZnKxksTSH37qm8cC/1478679877) concept before. This algorithm tries to rate every peer with a score. By changing the definition and domain of the weights, that algorithm can be very paranoid.
In a podcast on YouTube about ZeroNet, the host said by mistake that ZeroID used NameCoin. Actually, the `.bit` domains use NameCoins. However, it is very clever to use NameCoin to create IDs.

1_1Kn3RNTAmEKxnSLxNCYUGeCDPo4gsJHjQ8.body:
1) Things are stored in the `ZeroNet/data/1TaLk.../data/users/` folder. Your things are automatically signed and published to everyone else. Other people in this network will also store your things for you.

2)  You are NOT anonymous.

1_133PfjoNP94oHC3GczL9e7SCKoeKEMyCDJ.body:
> [anonymous3](#comment_1_1E7BcFiayaHgga2s3JhRpXfTE4rVUqFGgs): Thanks! Maybe you could experiment with storing files as hashes (more efficient, less bandwidth, less duplication).Like: files/0e/3e/0e3e75234abc68f4378a86b3f4b32a198ba301845b0cd6e50106e874345700ccThis is just a client-side optimization, won't need to require other peers to do the same as you.

Instead of changing directory tree, an easier way is to organize the hash sums of files into a database like file. We don't really want to change the directory tree.

If nofish wants ZeroNet to reuse existing files, he will probably choose to search for hash sums (information that shows two files are the same) in a data source (in any form). This "data source" can be represented either as directory tree or as a separate database.

1_18eGWSaM3Vc9i61LVfogjQJf5gp7EN7b9Y.body: I did not find any `<script>` tags or text containing `js` in `view-source:http://coppersurfer.tk/` over Tor.

It seems to be calling the GeoLocation API. I don't know if it contains code that makes use of exploits. Perhaps you can also post it to the Tor Mailing List, since people raised awareness on JavaScript exploits after a NIT was found.

https://lists.torproject.org/cgi-bin/mailman/listinfo
Here are all of Tor Project's mailing lists. An active talk for general discussion on the use of Tor and Internet censorship is the [tor-talk](https://lists.torproject.org/cgi-bin/mailman/listinfo/tor-talk) list. Perhaps you can get some advice from Tor's security researchers.

Interesting... I just googled the first line of the script. There is only one result that contains this script snippet. 
https://4gttzu6677777888utffffghh.blogspot.fr/2016/09/nsyteldetailpagecpnnpmqtqjsm4joxlfjdoci.html

Been trying different JS injectors to remove the element, but none of them offer either fine-grained enough filters or an option to inject the removal script prior to the self-deleting script. Any suggestions?

I guess your ISP is changing the content of coppersurfer.tk. Did you try using an encrypted proxy, VPN or the Tor Browser to visit coppersurfer.tk ?
By the way, The way the script sending the geo-location information back home is confusing.

4_18XR5C5AxGfD5s2DbCPGuXxVN5oscoLyD6.body: I can use AJAX without any problem. Did you try to request for an `.html` file? Requesting these kind of files are prohibited as to avoid sandbox escaping.

> [nofish](#comment_833_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): This version should work:https://gist.github.com/ilian/e8197b249fda2a312a2cec0f85b419c8
> I'm also planning to write a non-coffeescript tutorial. (site-type suggestions are welcome)

I hope ZeroNet will allow AJAX in the future. Cross Origin attacks can be mitigated by requiring the presence and correctness of referrer header for AJAX requests.

1_1Ni6LMewr5Cbc9fuKvdkSpS5bNm12vAKe4.body:
> 我想在零网内发布一个文件，应该在哪发呢？谢谢
> 如题，比如该文件是视频或者PDF又或者其它文件，谢谢

> I would like to publish a document in zero net, which should be made? Thank you
> If that, such as the document is video or PDF or other documents, thank you

1. put them on [IPFS](https://github.com/ipfs/ipfs)
2. put them on [Freenet](https://freenetproject.org/)
3. put them on other P2P software, such as [SyncThing](https://syncthing.net/)
4. make them torrents and put a magnet link on your site. [WebTorrent](https://webtorrent.io/)
4. For small files, put them directly on your ZeroNet site. [Example](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit/data/pdf/zeronet_presentation.pdf)
5. If you insist putting all of your files on ZeroNet, check out [ZeroMux Bundle](/1CiDoBP8RiWziqiBGEd8tQMy66A6fmnw2V/big/docs/)

1_18GMgG7f7mYquJC1RCphMRLhMX1wsxzxff.body: ZeroNet only has one developer, and he doesn't have experience on writing programs that run on mobile phones. However, there are people trying to make ZeroNet run on Android using Kivy framework, and people writing [alternative implementations](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1_133PfjoNP94oHC3GczL9e7SCKoeKEMyCDJ/ZeroNet+Golang+client) of ZeroNet.

> [christopherm](#comment_10_1DDCitotp8M6rCiHrNJ4VVLGTqXykLmD1t): @waterrabbit Can you post a link to running Zeronet using Kivy framework?

There is no usable mobile version or discussion on it, yet. Nofish mentioned running ZeroNet on Kivy would be a good idea, but no one had ever tried it out.

6_1C6qdRAX8iYqSB7TfUxk91yW8Y2SBKNgfA.body:
There are all kinds of standards for peer to peer systems, because people are exploring the ways to build a secure and reliable peer to peer system for the unreliable Internet.

I haven't read through the source code, but there are some generalized details on the front page:

> I am doing this all for **free** for **all humanity** because I hate evil. My #1 guiding moral principal is that **I am morally opposed to slavery in every form,** including the covert economic slavery powered by lies that is used today in all nations that claim they do not allow slavery. I do not believe in 'neccessary evil'. Infact, I know that there is no neccessary evil, such is only shortcuts which lead to destruction.



> (Libre and) **OPEN SOURCE**
> Written in **Python** and 100% open source, MORPHiS is intended to be free to open collaboration, transparency, and rapid prototyping. Lets work together to get this project off the ground!
> OPEN SOURCE **(GNU GPL v2)**

ZeroNet is also free and open source software.

> SECURE
> MORPHiS is a custom (enhanced with inventions) **Kademlia DHT** over a custom (enhanced with optimizations for performance in security) **SSH protocol.** MORPHiS is written in Python, a free and open language that is memory safe with high performance asynchronous I/O, and is not controlled by US/NSA corporations.

Nofish is working on a DHT that works through Tor. ZeroNet transfers signed contents with an additional protection layer of TLS.


> MODULAR
> The network is optimized for performance and low latency to allow for applications to be built on top of it using MORPHiS ames **TCP** to be 100% **compatible with TOR** so that it is as anonymous as TOR for those who connect their node through TOR to the MORPHiS network.

ZeroNet also supports Tor.


> WEB OF TRUST
> Through a **trust based system of reputation,** this feature will enable reputation based searches (deprecating GOOGLE/BING/ETC, DNS, and so on), forums (bye bye disqus, etc!), and eventually deprecating democracy and stone age government (democracy via stone age paper ballots VS real time direct voting).
 

> I have dedicated myself to this project. **Nothing** will stop me from completing **my life's work,** my **purpose in life.** This is my **calling.** I am and for years already been working on this full time; and I will continue to do so until I can say: it is finished!
> This is my **life's work.** I have been designing it, full-time, for years. I have been coding full-time since December of 2014. I am a **very good programmer** (at least with distributed systems, networks, databases, security, cryptography, and some other areas). This is my **purpose in life.** I have found my **calling!** I have a vision, and I am seeing it through until the end. That end is the **World Brain** peacefully overthrowing the existing system, world-wide.

1_1GAWwPWreQXo1CwcefCgL6w5wYPkNFWbsj.body: I ran into "content publish failed" simply because I could not connect to Tor. After I turned off Tor Always mode it finally works. "Content publish failed" doesn't necessarily mean that you run out of limit. You can double check your quota at your hub.
Your Blue Hub content is roughly 30.8 KB.

8_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nwkTkKv.body: While morally you can't make malware to infect old computers and create a large Zero-botnet, you should be aware that ZeroNet can run basically everywhere. NoFish runs ZeroNet on his $9 CHIP computer. Lots of people on ZeroMe host full-time nodes on Raspberry Pi. Furthermore, there is a guy who runs ZeroNet [on his router](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/783).

4_14UupgrdnT7Y8vMES7aqUFgD1fC5RYNrh8.body:
> [joczo](#comment_17_14UupgrdnT7Y8vMES7aqUFgD1fC5RYNrh8): I only have 400peers on 0chan..I don't understand this,cause in theory everybody should see the same amount of seeders from the tracker.Than how can that happen,that everyone sees different amounts...strange.

There are several ways in which ZeroNet can discover peer addresses. Peers addresses are fetched from trackers every 3 hours. Peers addresses, including `.onion` addresses, are exchanged between known peers. Once obtained, peer addresses are stored on the hard disk and will be loaded immediately at the next bootstrap. In addition to this, ZeroNet features a developing mechanism of down-voting slow peers.

The peer count you see depends on how much time you spent on ZeroNet.

1_12wGEUrb2N4oeNxs7bEjcV5GJe8VP9Cdsq.body:
Libre and Open Source is the baseline of privacy software. Never trust a proprietary software for its security and privacy. I felt a little disappointed when I saw there was no actual code pushed to Demonsaw's [GitHub repository](https://github.com/demonsaw).

The moderator of https://reddit.com/r/privacy emphasizes that:

If you find privacy related software, services or subreddits you think are great please run them by the mods before you post them. **Close source software is not permitted.**

The promotion of **closed** source privacy software is **not welcome** in /r/privacy. By its nature you can not verify easily that it does what it claims and as a result this puts your privacy and security at risk.

1_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd.body: It is definitely a threat to Git, but it is not a threat to ZeroNet **network protocol**. The protocol uses sha512 and Bitcoin's curve rather than sha1. The "infohash" of each site is just the sha1 hash of the Bitcoin address and is only used to aggregate peers together.

```python
>>> import base64
>>> import hashlib

>>> s = hashlib.sha512("Replace SHA-1 with stronger message digest functions!").digest()
>>> base64.b32encode(s)
'EYVH4MBTKSZQOARCINCZZXUARJFP2SY4GXZITGS27VSZKUANE27XMNUZZ52O6UP6GUKS3LMVSGWYVBKAL3CLY5AXKN4C4HDYLBY4J2A='
>>> new_infohash = base64.b32encode(s).lower().strip("=")
>>> new_urn = "bsha"
>>> new_maglink = "magnet:?xt=urn:%s:%s" % (new_urn, new_infohash)
>>> new_maglink
'magnet:?xt=urn:bsha:eyvh4mbtkszqoarcinczzxuarjfp2sy4gxzitgs27vszkuane27xmnuzz52o6up6guks3lmvsgwyvbkal3cly5axkn4c4hdylby4j2a'
```
Tor Hidden Service also uses SHA-1 as the digest algorithm of public keys. Fortunately the Tor Project is moving very fast to adopt the next generation Tor Onion Services.

2_1JwPBvZYXLJzrA6YisjpsyTuuieFLCARS6.body:
`".git"` should be `"\\.git"`. It is a regular expression.

`"files_allowed"` defines the allowed required files. In Red Hub, it says `(data.json|avatar.jpg|avatar.png)`

Each user has to define his or her own optional file rules in his or her own `content.json`. For instance, your own `content.json` in the Hub says `"optional": "(?!avatar).*jpg"`

```
>>> import re
>>> help(re.match)
Help on function match in module re:

match(pattern, string, flags=0)
    Try to apply the pattern at the start of the string, returning
    a match object, or None if no match was found.

>>> re.match("", "path/to/any/file.jpg")
<_sre.SRE_Match object at 0x0000000002D559F0>
```
